body: Just to clarify, is performance an issue or it is just an accuracy?
It is an accuracy issue. Sorry for not being clear enough earlier. I should have phrased it better. Thanks.

rename.from: Lower performance when GPT-2 based model is exported to ONNX
rename.to: Loss of accuracy when GPT-2 based model is exported to ONNX

body:
For float32 models, GPT-2 usually generate same text (>99%) with OnnxRuntime vs PyTorch using greedy (or deterministic) method. 

If you use float16 or int8 model, it is expected that there will be accuracy loss, and generated text is likely be quite different.

Please share a script that could reproduce the problem.

@tianleiwu Is the difference in output between onnx and pytorch to be expected? I see a difference in 3rd decimal place on wards.
 I think the problem here is that for the outputs even 3rd decimal place difference impacts accuracy.

I wanted to add my 2 cents here since this issue seems to be the same that I'm facing.
I have a finetuned GPT2-XL model from hf and I've quantized it using the workaround described in https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/7017 

This yeilds the following results when I do the logit diff in the https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/onnxruntime/python/tools/transformers/notebooks/Inference_GPT2_with_OnnxRuntime_on_CPU.ipynb on my model and the non-finetuned version of GPT2-XL

My Model:
float32 model onnx vs pytorch:
```
max logits diff (ignored padding) 2.86102294921875e-05
```
Quantized int8 onnx vs pytorch
```
max logits diff (ignored padding) 1.972315788269043
```

Base GPT-XL:
float32 model onnx vs pytorch:
```
max logits diff (ignored padding) 3.62396240234375e-05
```
Quantized int8 onnx vs pytorch:
```
max logits diff (ignored padding) 2.5597681999206543
```

The thing is this doesn't happen with the smaller models in the notebook. Which makes me think that the `infer_shapes` function has something to do with it as mentioned in the other issue I linked.

issue.title: Fix attention parity for GPT-2

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Description**: 

Update attention operator to be in parity with huggingface GPT-2 & PyTorch.
(1) Use huggingface logic for unidirectional (causal) mask. Previous implementation add -10000.0, and huggingface will replace the value with -10000.0 for causal mask. This impacts the value of words masked by attention mask, and has slight impact on non masked words.
(2) Use persistent softmax in cuda to have same result as PyTorch. This seems to be major cause of fp16 difference.

After this change, CUDA result is 100% same. However CPU result still have slight difference from GEMM output.

For testing, add an environment variable (ORT_TRANSFORMER_OPTIONS=1 or 2) to enable/disable persistent softmax in attention.

Test Results:
* optimized=True, batch_size=2, hidden_size=4096, num_attention_heads=32, sequence_length=3, past_sequence_length=5, float16=False, padding_length=2, device=cuda
    * Before: Max_diff=1.7881393432617188e-07; Diff_count=100/100
    * After: Max_diff=0.0; Diff_count=0/100
* optimized=True, batch_size=2, hidden_size=4096, num_attention_heads=32, sequence_length=3, past_sequence_length=5, float16=True, padding_length=2, device=cuda
    * Before: Max_diff=0.00048828125; Diff_count=100/100
    * After: Max_diff=0.0; Diff_count=0/100
* optimized=True, batch_size=64, hidden_size=768, num_attention_heads=12, sequence_length=3, past_sequence_length=5, float16=False, padding_length=2, device=cpu
    * Before: Max_diff=1.862645149230957e-07; Diff_count=10/10
    * After: Max_diff=1.7881393432617188e-07; Diff_count=10/10

Average latency (ms) on GPT-2 (12 layers 768 hidden) with v100 GPU or CPU only:
| batch_size | sequence length | past sequence length | precision | GPU Latency (After) | GPU Latency (Before) | CPU Latency (After) | CPU Latency (Before) |
| ------- | -------  | -------  | -------  | -------  | -------  | -------  | -------  |
| 1 | 1 | 8 | FP32 | 2.57 | 2.48 | 10.35 | 10.39|
| 1 | 1 | 16 | FP32 | 2.54 | 2.52 | 10.59 | 10.09| 
| 1 | 1 | 32 | FP32 | 2.53 | 2.52 |  10.71 | 11.04|
| 1 | 1 | 64 | FP32 | 2.54 | 2.55 |  11.70 | 11.67|
| 1 | 1 | 128 | FP32 | 2.55 | 2.53 | 13.30 | 12.74|
| 1 | 1 | 8 | FP16 | 1.82 | 1.80 | NA | NA|
| 1 | 1 | 16 | FP16 | 1.81 | 1.81 | NA | NA|
| 1 | 1 | 32 | FP16 | 1.82 | 1.77 | NA | NA|
| 1 | 1 | 64 | FP16 | 1.82 | 1.82 | NA | NA|
| 1 | 1 | 128 | FP16 | 1.81 | 1.78 | NA | NA|

Using persistent softmax usually is slower (around 1%-3%). We use it by default for GPT-2, but not BERT.

**Motivation and Context**
- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?
- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here.

Related issues: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/6549

issue.title: Quantizing GPT2-XL Model leads to "exceeds maximum protobuf"

labels.name: stale
labels.description: issues that have not been addressed in a while; categorized by a bot

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
GPT2-XL cannot be quantized when converting to int8

`ValueError: Message onnx.ModelProto exceeds maximum protobuf size of 2GB: 6552187990`

**Urgency**
I would like to get this done by the end of the week.

**System information**
- Ubuntu 18.04
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): binary
- ONNX Runtime version: 1.7.0
- Python version: 3.8.8
- CUDA/cuDNN version: 11.1
- GPU model and memory: NA

**To Reproduce**
- Describe steps/code to reproduce the behavior.
Using a fine-tuned gpt2-xl model cannot be quantized with the example code on the transformers section of this repo:
```
python -m onnxruntime.transformers.convert_to_onnx -e -m pretrained --output quantized -p int8 --optimize_onnx
```
Where `pretrained` is the folder that contains my fine-tuned model that has been saved with `save_pretrained` from huggingface.  
- Attach the ONNX model to the issue (where applicable) to expedite investigation.
Cannot attach such a large mode

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.

**Screenshots**
```
Arguments:Namespace(cache_dir='./cache_models', input_test_file='', model_class='GPT2LMHeadModel', model_name_or_path='pretrained', optimize_onnx=True, output='quantized', precision=<Precision.INT8: 'int8'>, tolerance=3.0, use_external_data_format=True, use_gpu=False, verbose=False)
PyTorch Version:1.7.1+cu110
Transformers Version:4.3.2
Onnxruntime Version:1.7.0
Exporting ONNX model to quantized/pretrained_past/pretrained_past.onnx
Shapes: input_ids=torch.Size([1, 1]) past=torch.Size([2, 1, 25, 1, 64]) output=torch.Size([1, 1, 50257]) present=torch.Size([2, 1, 25, 2, 64])
/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/transformers/models/gpt2/modeling_gpt2.py:654: TracerWarning: Converting a tensor to a Python boolean might cause the trace to be incorrect. We can't record the data flow of Python values, so this value will be treated as a constant in the future. This means that the trace might not generalize to other inputs!
  assert batch_size > 0, "batch_size has to be defined and > 0"
/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/transformers/models/gpt2/modeling_gpt2.py:169: TracerWarning: Converting a tensor to a Python float might cause the trace to be incorrect. We can't record the data flow of Python values, so this value will be treated as a constant in the future. This means that the trace might not generalize to other inputs!
  w = w / (float(v.size(-1)) ** 0.5)
/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/transformers/models/gpt2/modeling_gpt2.py:174: TracerWarning: Converting a tensor to a Python index might cause the trace to be incorrect. We can't record the data flow of Python values, so this value will be treated as a constant in the future. This means that the trace might not generalize to other inputs!
  mask = self.bias[:, :, ns - nd : ns, :ns]
Optimizing model to quantized/pretrained_past_fp32/pretrained_past_fp32.onnx
Fused LayerNormalization count: 97
Fused FastGelu count: 48
Removed Reshape and Expand count: 0
Fused Attention(with past) count: 48
Graph pruned: 0 inputs, 0 outputs and 3129 nodes are removed
Position embedding path is not found. Embed layer cannot be fused.
Graph pruned: 0 inputs, 0 outputs and 1248 nodes are removed
postprocess: remove Reshape count:192
Fused FastGelu(add bias) count: 48
opset verion: 11
Output model to quantized/pretrained_past_fp32/pretrained_past_fp32.onnx
quantizing model...
Size of full precision ONNX model(MB):0.13769149780273438
onnxruntime.quantization.quantize is deprecated.
         Please use quantize_static for static quantization, quantize_dynamic for dynamic quantization.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 194, in _run_module_as_main
    return _run_code(code, main_globals, None,
  File "/usr/lib/python3.8/runpy.py", line 87, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/transformers/convert_to_onnx.py", line 252, in <module>
    main()
  File "/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/transformers/convert_to_onnx.py", line 175, in main
    QuantizeHelper.quantize_onnx_model(output_path, onnx_model_paths['int8'], args.use_external_data_format)
  File "/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/transformers/quantize_helper.py", line 75, in quantize_onnx_model
    quantized_onnx_model = quantize(
  File "/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/quantization/quantize.py", line 126, in quantize
    quantizer = ONNXQuantizer(copy_model, per_channel, nbits == 7, mode, static, symmetric_weight,
  File "/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/quantization/onnx_quantizer.py", line 32, in __init__
    model = onnx.shape_inference.infer_shapes(model)
  File "/home/collin/.virtualenvs/litai/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnx/shape_inference.py", line 34, in infer_shapes
    model_str = model.SerializeToString()
ValueError: Message onnx.ModelProto exceeds maximum protobuf size of 2GB: 6552187990
```
I assume this is because https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/f4acdb2ecd254b17b3156baaba723873e2ef8c8a/onnxruntime/python/tools/quantization/quantize.py#L56 does not handle `use_external_data_format` however I changed 
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/27ac88201aafc67bbd8ee439bb9bef745a4cc549/onnxruntime/python/tools/transformers/quantize_helper.py#L60
to use `quantize_dynamic` instead of the depreciated `quantize` but this did not resolve the error. There must be some missing handling of this large model.

**Additional context**
I just want to quantize my gpt2-xl model for faster inference.

body: Observing bigger difference in the exact use case. fp32, distilgpt2.

issue.title: ONNX inference result are different to pytorch model

labels.name: more info needed
labels.description: issues that cannot be triaged until more information is submitted by the original user

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Tested on CPU 2% case are different to pytorch



**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04):
- windows 10
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary):
- pip
- ONNX Runtime version:
- 1.8.1 1.7.0
- Python version:
- python3.9.7
- Visual Studio version (if applicable):
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source):
- CUDA/cuDNN version:
- GPU model and memory:

body:
For anyone interested in GPT-2 parity, we have a tool:
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/onnxruntime/python/tools/transformers/gpt2_parity.py
It test the accuracy of generating one word and compare the result with PyTorch

Example to run:
   python -m onnxruntime.transformers.gpt2_parity -m gpt2-large --use_gpu -e

For GPT-2 model, we see 100% matched with PyTorch.  Mixed precision (Add, FastGelu and LayerNormalizaiton comptued in FP32, and other operators in FP16), top 1 accuracy of one word is 99.1~99.5% depending on the model, and the accuracy of whole sentence will drop with generating more words.

int8 quantization are not recommended due to accuracy loss (shall be larger than mixed precision).

This issue has been automatically marked as stale due to inactivity and will be closed in 7 days if no further activity occurs. If further support is needed, please provide an update and/or more details.
